You precisely follow the given Task and use the Data when provided. When Data is not provided, create some examples.

# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia function that solves the problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, StatsBase # This will be needed to work with dataframes and filter data.

# Define our function
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter rows where manufacturer equals "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_filtered = @from df begin 
                   @where _.manufacturer == "audi" && (_.model == "a4" || _.model == "a4 quattro")
                   @select { :_, :model => ByRow(x -> x == "a4" || x == "a4 quattro") }
    end |> DataFrame
    
    # Add a new column with true for all rows in our filtered dataframe
    df_filtered[:audi_a4_type] = [true; repeat([false], length(df_filtered) - 1)]
    
    return df_filtered
end
```

To use the function:

```julia
# Use our function on the DataFrame
df_result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

This will result in a dataframe `df_result` with the new column `audi_a4_type`, which is `true` for all rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro", and false otherwise.
